title: Duck Eats Yeast, Quacks, Explodes; Man Loses Eye
subtitle: Poultry shows are all fun and games until someone loses an eye.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: An Iowa man lost the sight in one eye when his prize-winning duck ate a pan of yeast and exploded.

title: Did Stalin Pluck a Live Chicken as a Lesson to His Followers?
subtitle: A common tale expresses the thought that a dictator can do anything he wants to "the people," so long as the people believe he is the source of their survival.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Soviet leader Josef Stalin ripped the feathers off a live chicken to demonstrate "how easy it is to govern stupid people."

title: Did NFL Star Patrick Mahomes Buy Dinner for All Patrons at a Restaurant?
subtitle: The Kansas City Chiefs' quarterback helped his team win the Super Bowl on Feb. 2, 2020.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Kansas City Chiefs' quarterback Patrick Mahomes once bought dinner for everyone at a restaurant because they didn't bother him for an autograph.

title: Is Indianapolis' Area Code a Tribute to the Survivors of a Naval Tragedy?
subtitle: A local legend connects the 1945 sinking of the USS
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: The city of Indianapolis was assigned the 317 area code as a tribute to the number of survivors of the sinking of the USS

title: Is the 'Poltergeist' Curse Real?
subtitle: Superstitious legend holds that a number of strange deaths are connected to a 'curse' on the 'Poltergeist' film series.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: The

title: Urban Legend: Drilled Wire
subtitle: A competitor one-ups a company proud of their new ultra-thin wire by drilling a hole through it.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A competitor one-ups a company proud of their new ultra-thin wire by drilling a hole through it.

title: Child Abducts Penguin in Backpack?
subtitle: Urban legend holds that a child successfully smuggled a penguin out of an amusement park by concealing the creature in his backpack.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A child successfully smuggled a penguin out of an amusement park by concealing the creature in his backpack.

title: Delivery Person Mistaken for Troll
subtitle: Legend about a developmentally disabled adult who captures a delivery person (or other front door caller), believing him to be a troll.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A developmentally disabled adult captured a delivery person, Jehovah's Witness, or salesman after mistaking him for a troll.

title: What's in the 'Pulp Fiction' Briefcase?
subtitle: The question of what the briefcase sought by the main characters in 'Pulp Fiction' contained is one of filmdom's most enduring mysteries.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: The briefcase retrieved by Vincent Vega and Jules Winnfield in the film

title: 'Cheapskate' Brags About Pressuring Waiter for $5 Tip
subtitle: A meme promoting an alleged "experiment" was strikingly similar to a scene from some NBC sitcoms.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: A couple determined their tip to a waitress by dangling five $1 bills at their table.

title: China's 'Three Squeaks' Live Mice Dish
subtitle: Rumors about a Chinese live mice dish called 'Three Squeaks" have been circulating for several years, but evidence of its existence is lacking.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A popular dish in China called "Three Squeaks" involves eating live mice.

title: September 11 Adultery Revelation
subtitle: A 9/11-related legend played on the idea of the disaster's trapping a man into inadvertently revealing his adulterous activities to his wife
author: Snopes Staff
statement: The 9/11 terrorist attacks trapped a World Trade Center worker into inadvertently revealing his adulterous activities to his wife.

title: Marine's Letter Home
subtitle: A farm kid's humorous letter home describes life as a Marine.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A farm kid's humorous letter home describes life as a Marine.

title: Was Star Trek's Chekov Inspired by Pravda?
subtitle: Legend holds that the character of Pavel Chekov was added to 'Star Trek' in response to an editorial in the Russian newspaper Pravda.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The character of Ensign Chekov was added to the television series 'Star Trek' because an editorial in the Communist newspaper Pravda had criticized the lack of a Soviet crewman on board the U.S.S. Enterprise.

title: Rope-a-Dope Deer
subtitle: A farmer who attempted to rope a deer described the hilariously painful experience.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A farmer who attempted to rope a deer described the hilariously painful experience.

title: In Case of Intruder, Should You Ask 911 for a Pizza?
subtitle: What began as a story about a domestic violence victim's purported call to 911 "for a pizza" evolved into unsubstantiated advice about calling emergency services.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A woman managed to call 911 during a domestic abuse incident by pretending to order a pizza.

title: Definitely Not Friends of Dorothy
subtitle: Prevalent racism legend holds that a Las Vegas hotel once completely drained their pool because black entertainer Dorothy Dandridge stuck her toe in the water.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: In the 1950s, a Las Vegas hotel completely drained their pool because black entertainer Dorothy Dandridge stuck her toe in the water.

title: Sex Roulette
subtitle: A number of tabloids are reporting rumors that a risky new "sex roulette" trend - involving orgies where at least one attendee is HIV-positive - are "on the rise."
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: "Sex roulette" is a new sexual trend in which one attendee at an orgy is HIV-positive.

title: 57 Varieties of Truth
subtitle: A tale about how Temple Baptist Church was built on land bought with 57 cents donated by a little girl has grown in the telling.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Temple Baptist Church was built on land sold for fifty-seven cents, the amount saved by a little girl who had been turned away from its Sunday school.

title: Is Hell Endothermic or Exothermic?
subtitle: Old collegiate legend involves a student's coming up with a clever proof about the physical properties of Hell.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A student came up with a clever proof and pithy saying in response to an exam question about the physical properties of Hell.

title: False Authority
subtitle: The bare-faced truth about all those Lost Legends at snopes.com
author: David Mikkelson

title: The Rose
subtitle: Penpals for more than a year, a woman and a returning war veteran decide to meet-will he pass her test?
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Wartime penpals arrange to meet at Grand Central Station: he will know her by the rose in her lapel, and she will know him by how he reacts to it.

title: Did a Woman Sew Shrimp Into Curtains to Get Even With Her Cheating Partner?
subtitle: Something smells fishy.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A jilted woman sews shrimp into the curtain hems of the house she shares with her lover, and the impossible-to-locate stench drives him and his new lady love to sell the house.

title: Is the Word 'Sex' Hidden in 'The Lion King'?
subtitle: Viewers claim that clouds of dust form the word S-E-X in  the Disney animated film 'The Lion King.'
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The letters S-E-X are formed by a swirling cloud of dust in

title: Who Stripped Jessica Rabbit
subtitle: Prankish Disney animators supposedly drew Jessica Rabbit without underwear in a few frames of 'Who Framed Roger Rabbit.'
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Disney animators drew Jessica Rabbit without underwear in a few frames of 'Who Framed Roger Rabbit.'

title: The $50 Porsche
subtitle: Did a woman sell her partner's expensive new car for $50 after he ran off with a younger woman?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Woman sells her partner's expensive new car for $50 after he runs off with a younger woman.

title: Does the Minister in 'Little Mermaid' Get an Erection?
subtitle: A longstanding rumor maintains the minister officiating Ursula's wedding in 'The Little Mermaid' is more than enthusiastic about his job.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The minister officiating at Ursula's wedding ceremony in

title: April Fools' Day Origins
subtitle: The origins of April Fools' Day.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: April Fools' Day began in the 1500s when the Gregorian calendar took over from the Julian. Those who forgot the change and attempted to celebrate New Year's (previously celebrated on the 1st of April) on the wrong date were teased as "April fools."

title: Did a Rammed Car Cause a Pregnancy?
subtitle: An amorous couple engaged in a parked car were rammed from behind by another vehicle, leading to an unplanned pregnancy and a lawsuit.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: An amorous couple engaged in a parked car were rammed from behind by another vehicle, leading to an unplanned pregnancy and a lawsuit.

title: Etymology of 86
subtitle: Did the term '86' (to get rid of someone or something) enter the English language as part of a restaurant code?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The term

title: Holiday Party
subtitle: E-mails from a company's Human Resources Director document the difficulties of office holiday party planning.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: E-mails from a company's Human Resources Director document the difficulties of office holiday party planning.

title: The Boyfriend's Death
subtitle: Was the boyfriend who went for gasoline murdered by a madman?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Hours after sending her boyfriend in search of gasoline, a girl is rescued from her stranded car by police. Though cautioned not to turn around, she does...and sees her boyfriend's lifeless body hanging from a tree branch above the car.

title: Quake Mother
subtitle: Mother leaves touching text message for the child she died shielding during an earthquake.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Did a mother leave a touching text message for the child she died shielding during an earthquake?

title: Is This Child's Name for Real?
subtitle: The tale of a mother who names her child 'Le-a,' which she insists be pronounced 'Ledasha.'
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A mother named her child "Le-a," which she insists be pronounced "Ledasha."

title: The Bedbug Letter
subtitle: Apology letter to wronged customer is marred by attached instructions to send the standard form letter.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Apology letter sent to a wronged customer is marred by attached instructions to send the recipient the standard grovel.

title: Superglue Revenge
subtitle: Wife takes revenge on a philandering husband by supergluing his penis to his leg.
author: David Mikkelson

title: Obnoxious Airline Passengers
subtitle: A bigoted and obnoxious airline passenger demanding special treatment gets more than he bargained for.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A bigoted and obnoxious airline passenger demanding special treatment gets more than he bargained for.

title: Toronto's Clean Streets
subtitle: Did Toronto sanitation workers clean up a street deliberately littered for a film shoot?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A Toronto film crew returning from a break found their intentionally garbage-strewn street had been cleaned by sanitation workers.

title: Guilty American Motorists
subtitle: Canadian police stop malfunctioning vehicle; American occupants immediately assume 'about to be frisked' position.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: When Canadian police stop a malfunctioning vehicle, the American occupants immediately assume an "about to be frisked" position.

title: Home Intruder Poses as Clown Statue
subtitle: Remember this tale about a babysitter who makes an unfortunate discovery?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A clown statue that spooked a babysitter turns out to be a knife-wielding intruder hiding in the house.

title: The Babysitter and the Man Upstairs
subtitle: A babysitter receives mysterious, threatening phone calls.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A babysitter left alone in charge of sleeping children receives several mysterious, threatening phone calls.

title: Why Are Coins Left on Headstones?
subtitle: Modern tradition holds that leaving coins on military tombstones denotes visits from living soldiers.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Coins left on military tombstones denote visits from living soldiers.

title: Expense Account Reveals Adultery?
subtitle: Did the details of an expense account reveal an ongoing affair between an executive and his stenographer?
author: David Mikkelson

subtitle: Are green M&Ms an aphrodisiac?
author: David Mikkelson

title: 'Wizard of Oz' Coat Belonged to L. Frank Baum?
subtitle: Was a coat belonging to 'Oz' author L. Frank Baum coincidentally used in the MGM film version of 'The Wizard of Oz'?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A second-hand coat selected as part of the costume for Professor Marvel in the 1939 film version of

title: Have Babies Been Named After Embarrassing Medical Terms?
subtitle: "There was this paper on her incubator that said 'Please save Urine,' so I knew that they had named my baby."
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A woman christens her baby with a name based on an embarrassing medical term or bodily part after overhearing one of the nurses use the word.

title: Did Camel Cigarettes Packs Include a 'Hidden Naked Man'?
subtitle: Many consumers claimed to be able to see a naked man hidden in the artwork of Camel cigarette packages.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: The image of a naked man is hidden in the artwork of Camel cigarette packs.

title: A Message from the Chinese Restaurant Association of the United States?
subtitle: A photograph purportedly shows a holiday time 'thank you' sign to Jews posted by the Chinese Restaurant Association of the U.S.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Photograph shows a "thank you" sign to Jews from the Chinese Restaurant Association of the United States.

title: Unbelievable Turkey Stories to Share at Your Thanksgiving Table
subtitle: We will always be thankful for this compendium of Thanksgiving turkey humor.
author: Snopes Staff

title: Call Girl John's Daughter
subtitle: Did the call girl sent to a man's room turn out to be his daughter?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The hooker sent to a john's room turns out to be his daughter.

title: Ghostly Moth Saves Train
subtitle: Did a ghostly figure produced by a moth save a train from traversing a washed-out bridge?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A ghostly figure produced by a moth saved a train from traversing a washed-out bridge.

title: Long Distance Bill Revenge
subtitle: Woman gets revenge on former boyfriend by calling long-distance number and leaving his phone off the hook.
author: David Mikkelson

title: Are Green Cars Unlucky?
subtitle: To those of a superstitious bent, green cars seem far more prone than those of other hue to develop mysterious ailments and proclivities.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Green is an unlucky color for automobiles.

title: What's Behind the 'No Bananas on a Boat' Superstition?
subtitle: Bananas are deemed unlucky by recreational fishermen and those catering to that trade.
statement: Bananas on a fishing boat are unlucky.

title: Snappy Answers to Dumb Olympics Questions
subtitle: List of snappy answers to dumb Olympic Games tourist questions.
author: David Mikkelson

title: Do Sneakers Hanging from Power Lines Carry a Secret Message?
subtitle: Contrary to what one hears, there's no one right answer as to why people practice 'shoefiti' or shoe tossing.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Old running shoes hanging from trees and power lines are 'gang signs.'

title: The Cab Ride
subtitle: Sentimental tale about a cab driver taking an elderly woman to a hospice on the last ride of her life.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Account describes a cab driver taking an elderly woman to a hospice on the last ride of her life.

title: Baby Smothered Under Pile of Coats?
subtitle: Tragic tale tells of a baby left on a bed who is smothered under coats carelessly dropped by Christmas guests.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A baby left on a bed is smothered under coats dropped by Christmas visitors.

title: 'Frozen Brain' Shoplifter
subtitle: Did a shoplifter who stashed a frozen chicken under her hat die of 'frozen brain'?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Shoplifter who attempts to conceal a chicken under her hat is caught when the frozen loot renders her unconscious.

title: The Tale of the Lost Exam Page
subtitle: This story tells of a student who hatched a plan to finish his exam outside of class, only later to pretend the page had been dropped in the classroom.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A student completed his exam outside of class, returned it to the classroom and dropped it on the floor, and waited for someone to find it and turn it in.

title: The Tale of the Lost Blue Book
subtitle: This is the story of a student who was unable to answer an exam question, so he hatched a scheme to still receive a good grade.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Faced with a test question he cannot answer, a student tricks his instructor into believing that one of his exam booklets was lost.

title: The Stolen Biscuits
subtitle: A long-circulating tale of biscuit banditry.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The stranger sharing an old lady's table at a cafe keeps helping himself to what she thinks are her cookies.

title: Trained Professor
subtitle: Students purportedly used conditioning techniques to influence psychology instructor into lecturing from specific part of classroom.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Students used conditioning techniques to influence a psychology instructor into lecturing from specific part of classroom.

title: The Tale of the Bird Foot Exam
subtitle: Responding to your college professor with a one-liner might not get you an A on an exam, but it may make for a satisfying story.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A student who was dissatisfied with her visual biology exam showed up her professor by responding with a zinger and a visual of her own.

title: The Tale of the Anonymous Test Taker
subtitle: Perhaps this exam proctor should have placed finished exams a bit farther out of reach.
author: David Mikkelson

title: The Tale of the Mailed Blue Book
subtitle: Legend tells of a plan to finish an exam after the testing period ended by enlisting his mother, two blue books, and a postmark.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Faced with an examination question he cannot answer, a student pretends to have accidentally mailed one of his blue books to his mother.

title: Did Baby Food Jars Horrify African Consumers?
subtitle: Understanding where this decades-old tale came from is to see cultural prejudice at work.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: African consumers were horrified by an American baby food company's product packaging.

title: Cruise Control as Auto-Pilot
subtitle: Legend holds that an unfamiliar driver set the cruise control on his vehicle and then slipped into the backseat for a nap.
author: Snopes Staff

title: Deposit Slip Scam
subtitle: A get-rich scheme supposedly involved a scammer's leaving blank deposit slips imprinted with his account number in banks for unwitting customers to use.
author: David Mikkelson

title: The Super Bowl Indicator
subtitle: Does the Super Bowl winner predict annual stock market performance?
author: David Mikkelson

title: The Salami Embezzlement Technique
subtitle: A bank employee supposedly furtively amassed a large sum of ill-gotten gains by stealing very small amounts of money from many different accounts over time.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A bank employee embezzled a large sum by stealing small amounts of money from many different accounts.

title: The Vanishing Hitchhiker
subtitle: The tale of a ghostly hitchhiker who disappears from a car.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A man turns to bid his unusual hitchhiker goodbye and discovers that she has disappeared from the car. He later learns that his mysterious passenger had died several years earlier.

title: Cement in Lover's Car Revenge?
subtitle: Did a man fill a Cadillac supposedly belonging to his wife's lover with concrete?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Man who drives a cement mixer for a living notices a strange car parked in his driveway and assumes the owner is having an affair with his wife; as revenge he fills the car with concrete, only to discover that the car was a present from his wife.

title: Bear Mauls Honey-Smeared Child
subtitle: Urban legend about a photo opportunity involving a bear and a honey-smeared kid going horribly wrong.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A photo opportunity involving a bear and a honey-smeared child resulted in a terrible mauling.

title: Amputee Legend
subtitle: Did a badly wounded soldier tell his parents about his injuries under the guise of them happening to a friend, only to prompt the wrong reaction?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A badly injured soldier tells his parents about his lifestyle-altering injuries under the guise of presenting them as a tragedy that befell a friend.

title: Beheaded Child on Schoolbus
subtitle: Was a little girl hanging out of a school bus window decapitated by a road sign?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A little girl whose habit it was to hang her head out the school bus window was decapitated by a road sign.

title: What Does a Sun Shower Symbolize?
subtitle: Folklore supplies two "reasons" for sun showers, one having to do with animals, the other with the devil or witches.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Rain that falls during a sun shower brings good luck.

title: Chop Suey Origins
subtitle: Chop Suey: American or Chinese?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The popular Chinese dish chop suey is actually American.

title: Dog Mouths vs. Human Mouths
subtitle: Some people say dogs' mouths are yucky; others assert they're cleaner than human mouths.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A dog's mouth is cleaner than a human's.

title: NASCAR Peanuts Superstition
subtitle: Why are peanuts in the shell considered to be unlucky at auto racing events?
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Peanuts in the shell are unlucky at auto racing events.

title: No Price Too High
subtitle: A lesson in how one lone punctuation mark can have a profound impact on the meaning of a sentence.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A punctuation error of a missing comma in a telegram resulted in a costly mistake.

title: Don't Forget the Coffee!
subtitle: Urban legend about an airline pilot who inadvertently makes risqué comment over an open microphone.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: An airline pilot who inadvertently made a risqué comment over an open microphone.

title: The Chicken Cannon
subtitle: British train engineers supposedly received help from the FAA about the proper use of a chicken launcher.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: The U.S. Federal Aviation Administration offered the British an obvious piece of advice after being asked to investigate a train-testing mishap.

title: Was a Woman Fatally Bitten by a Snake in Her Coat Pocket?
subtitle: You never know when you may come across your worst fears.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A woman is fatally bitten by a snake found in the pocket of her new winter coat.

title: Was a Mayoral Election Won by a Foot Powder?
subtitle: An election-themed deodorant ad campaign supposedly prompted the residents of a small Ecuadorian town to vote a foot powder into office as mayor.
author: David Mikkelson

title: Did an Atheist Professor Test God by Dropping a Breakable Object?
subtitle: Multiple versions of the tale go back as far as the 1920s, involving the failure to drop and break a piece of chalk, a glass beaker, or an egg.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: An atheist professor challenged God to keep a breakable object from shattering when he dropped it to the ground.

title: Trade AA Medallions for Free Drinks?
subtitle: Can an Alcoholics Anonymous member exchange his sobriety medallion for free drinks at any bar?
author: David Mikkelson

title: The Baby Train
subtitle: Did a town with a loud early morning train experience unusually high birth rates?
author: David Mikkelson

title: AIDS Mary
subtitle: A long-circulating urban legend, "AIDS Mary," holds that a woman seduces men with the intent of infecting them with HIV.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The morning after a one-night fling, a man walks into his bathroom and finds the words “WELCOME TO THE WORLD OF AIDS” scrawled on the mirror in lipstick.

title: Wing and a Prayer
subtitle: Anecdote tells of the pilot of a disabled bomber who went down with the plane in order to comfort a gunner trapped in a turret.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: The pilot of a disabled bomber went down with the plane in order to comfort a gunner trapped in a turret.

title: Was a Volkswagen Beetle and Its Passengers Crushed Between Two Trucks?
subtitle: Beep, beep. Crushed punch buggy.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Two large trucks that had collided head-on are pulled apart weeks later, revealing that a Volkswagen Beetle and its occupants had been crushed between them.

title: Breaking a Mirror
subtitle: Why should the act of breaking a mirror bring one seven years of bad luck?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Breaking a mirror brings seven years of bad luck.

title: Lucky Kit Kat
subtitle: Do Kit Kat chocolate bars bring luck to Japanese students during exams?
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Kit Kat chocolate bars bring luck to Japanese students during exams.

title: Is the Bloody Mary Story True?
subtitle: Will chanting 'Bloody Mary' 13 times in front of a darkened mirror summon a vengeful ghost?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Chanting "Bloody Mary!" thirteen times in front of a candlelit mirror will summon a vengeful spirit.

title: Baby High Chair Death
subtitle: Was a baby left in a high chair to await the sitter discovered dead when his vacationing parents returned weeks later?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Baby left in a high chair to await the coming of the sitter is discovered dead by the vacationing parents when they return weeks later.

title: Aren't You Glad You Didn't Turn on the Light?
subtitle: A college student makes a horrifying discovery.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A female college student returns to her dorm room late one evening and discovers her roommate has been murdered.

title: The Hook
subtitle: An escaped killer interrupts a young couple's make-out session.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A couple's late night make-out session is cut short when they hear a report on the car radio about an escaped killer (who has a hook for a hand) in the vicinity. The girl insists on being driven home immediately; upon arrival at her house, the boy discovers a bloody hook hanging from the passenger-side car door handle.

title: Transfusion Confusion
subtitle: The tear-jerking tale of a little boy who selflessly agreed to transfuse his sister, believing the procedure would kill him.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A brave little boy agrees to transfuse his ailing little sister, thinking the procedure will kill him even as it saves her life.

title: Faces in the Cloud
subtitle: Do photos of the World Trade Center fire reveal the face of Satan?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Images of the World Trade Center fire reveal the face of Satan.

title: $20 Bill Folding
subtitle: Does a properly folded U.S. $20 bill reveal images of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A properly folded U.S. $20 bill reveals images of the September 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.

title: Did a Snake Kill a Child on a Ride?
subtitle: Such tales have been told of just about every amusement park in the nation.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Child on amusement park ride is fatally bitten by snakes lurking within.

title: Which Gemstones Are Unlucky?
subtitle: It seems some gems and stones can carry good or bad luck, depending on how you use them.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Luck and ill-luck attributed to a variety of gems.

title: Craigslist Gold Digger
subtitle: Woman advertises on Craigslist for a rich husband, receives advice about 'depreciating assets.'
statement: A woman who advertised on Craigslist for a rich husband received advice from a potential life partner about 'depreciating assets.'

title: ICE Badges
subtitle: E-mail describes ruse intended to scare away littering Mexican construction workers.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: E-mail describes ruse intended to scare away littering Mexican construction workers.

title: Ken Olsen
subtitle: Did Digital founder Ken Olsen say there was 'no reason for any individual to have a computer in his home'?
author: David Mikkelson

title: Risqué 'Star Wars' C-3P0 Trading Card
subtitle: A 1977 'Star Wars' trading card seemingly depicted C-3P0 with an oversized appendage.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A Star Wars trading card was altered to depict the droid C-3P0 with an oversized penis.

title: Father of the Bribe
subtitle: Did a sheriff attempt to extort sexual favors from an underage girl, only to discover that she's his own daughter?
author: David Mikkelson

title: Questions Asked of Park Rangers
subtitle: Dumb questions purportedly asked of park rangers by tourists.
author: David Mikkelson

title: Old Lady's Sweet 'Thank You' Letter Takes Vitriolic Turn
subtitle: A woman in a nursing home who received the gift of a radio supposedly penned an interesting 'thank you' letter.
author: Snopes Staff

title: U.S. Grant's Exploding Cigar Practical Joke
subtitle: The famous general supposedly once handed out an exploding cigar that paid off decades later.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Ulysses S. Grant once handed out an exploding cigar that paid off decades later.

title: Why Is Friday the 13th Unlucky?
subtitle: It's a question people appear to have pondered for centuries.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Friday the 13th is a day fraught with peril.

title: Dating Disasters: The Dog Watch
subtitle: A young man tries to distract his date's parents from his dinnertime faux pas by inadvertently calling their attention to an even more embarrassing situation.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A young man tries to distract his date's parents from his dinnertime faux pas by inadvertently calling their attention to an even more embarrassing situation.

title: 'Leap Day' Proposal
subtitle: Once upon a time, the notion of women proposing marriage to men was an aberration.
statement: Custom allows marriage-minded women to propose to their boyfriends on Feb. 29 ("leap day").

title: Are Birds Flying into Your House Bad Luck?
subtitle: Whatever it means, it never feels like good news.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A wild bird flying into one's house is a portent of ill luck, possibly even death.

title: The Physics of Santa and His Reindeer
subtitle: A tongue-in-cheek scientific analysis of Santa's toy delivery process.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Article describes the physics involved in Santa's delivering presents all over the world.

title: Martha Stewart Snub
subtitle: A rumored encounter between Martha Stewart and David Rockefeller has been dismissed as a tall tale.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Martha Stewart is refused the use of a telephone, only to discover greater celebrities are also denied access to it.

title: Did a Taco Bell Employee Refuse a $2 Bill?
subtitle: The tale of a Taco Bell employee who refused to accept a less common form of currency because he thought it wasn't real.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A Taco Bell employee refused a $2 bill from a customer because he thought it wasn't real.

title: Gaylord Perry's 'Moon Shot' Home Run
subtitle: Did Gaylord Perry's manager predict he'd hit his first home only after men had walked on the moon?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Pitcher Gaylord Perry fulfilled his manager's prophecy by hitting his first home run minutes after Apollo 11 landed on the lunar surface.

title: Cats Sacrificed at Halloween?
subtitle: Rumor has it that black cats are subjected to all sorts of unkind and even cruel activity around Halloween.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Black cats are routinely sacrificed by "satanic cults" at Halloween.

title: Heeding the Call
subtitle: Did a man contemplating suicide receive a phone call from Almighty God?
statement: Man contemplating suicide asks God for a sign and receives a phone call from Almighty God.

title: The Unfinishable Haunted House
subtitle: Does a Halloween haunted house attraction exist that is so scary no one has ever finished it?
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Somewhere in the U.S. is a haunted house attraction so scary that no visitor has ever completed a tour of it.

title: Cremains Mistaken for Cocaine
subtitle: Thieves steal 'cocaine' which turns out to be the cremated remains of a householder's relative.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Thieves steal what they believe to be cocaine but what is in reality the cremated remains of the householder's relative.

title: Did Houdini Die from a Punch to the Stomach?
subtitle: Did escape artist Harry Houdini die from a ruptured appendix caused by a punch in the stomach?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Escape artist Harry Houdini died from a ruptured appendix caused by his being punched in the stomach.

title: The Handyman's Invoice
subtitle: The bill of a famed fix-it man detailed the difference between value of work and value of knowledge.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: The bill presented by a famed fix-it man detailed the difference between value of work done and value of the knowledge behind it.

title: Did a Father Sacrifice His Son for a Train Full of Passengers?
subtitle: The story of a father's choice between saving his own son or a train full of people goes back long before it was published online.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A father was faced with the horrifying choice between saving his son's life at the cost of many, or watching his son die as his inaction saves others.

title: Are Santa's Reindeer All Female?
subtitle: We turn to the University of Alaska Fairbanks and Alaska's Department of Fish and Game for this legend.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: All of the reindeer that pull Santa's sleigh are female.

title: Turkey Neck
subtitle: Did you hear that one about the kids who left a turkey neck sticking out of Dad's pants?
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Prankish kids leave a turkey neck sticking out of Dad's pants; Mom faints when she sees the cat gnawing on it.

title: Was John Michael Montgomery's Song 'The Little Girl' Based on a True Story?
subtitle: "We don't have a clue, but if it ain't true, it ought to be."
author: Snopes Staff
statement: John Michael Montgomery's song "The Little Girl" is based on a true story.

title: Death by Playing Cards
subtitle: Legend holds that a prisoner killed himself using a deck of playing cards.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A prisoner killed himself using a deck of playing cards.

title: The Killer in the Backseat
subtitle: A crazed killer is discovered hiding in the back seat of woman's car at a gas station.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A good Samaritan warns a female driver about the armed and dangerous man hiding in the back seat of her car.

title: Ice Cream in Purse
subtitle: A woman is so overwhelmed a meeting a celebrity in an ice cream parlor that she inadvertently puts her ice cream cone into her purse.
statement: A woman is so overwhelmed a meeting a celebrity in an ice cream parlor that she inadvertently puts her ice cream cone into her purse.

title: The Sinking Library
subtitle: A college library is said to be sinking into the ground because the architect failed to take the weight of the books into account.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A famed college library is sinking into the ground because its architect failed to take the weight of the books into account.

title: Did a Student Demand 'Cakes and Ale' During a Test?
subtitle: Legend has it that a student sitting for an exam requested his professor bring the provisions under a centuries-old university regulation.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Student sitting for exam requests cakes and ale under a centuries-old university regulation.

title: Which Tire?
subtitle: In the parlance of today's students, one might call this instructor's move a "sick burn."
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Students who offer a flat tire as an excuse for missing an exam are given a special make-up exam.

title: He Loves Me, He Loves Me Not?
subtitle: A woman discovers via a radio program call-in stunt that her long-time boyfriend is married.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A woman shockingly found out via a radio program call-in stunt that her long-time boyfriend was married.

title: The Ultimate Fruitcake Recipe
subtitle: Versions of this holiday gag have been kicking around for decades.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Narrative provides instructions for concocting the ultimate fruitcake.

title: Grandma's Cooking Secret
subtitle: A bride finally questions why her mother cuts the ends off of roasts before cooking them.
statement: A bride finally questions why her mother cuts the ends off of roasts before cooking them.

title: Santa Hung on a Cross in Japan?
subtitle: Did a Japanese department store once display Santa Claus nailed to a cross?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A Japanese department store once created a Christmas display featuring a smiling Santa Claus nailed to a cross.

title: Batman with a Twist
subtitle: Man dressed as superhero knocks himself unconscious after tying his wife to the bed.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Man dressed as superhero knocks himself unconscious after tying his wife to the bed.

title: 'Pencil Death' Exam Suicide
subtitle: The high-pressure environment of college has led to many legends that express the stresses and anxieties felt by students.
author: David Mikkelson

title: The Tale of 'Wash. Biol. Surv.'
subtitle: "I followed the cooking instructions on the leg tag and I want to tell you it was horrible."
author: Snopes Staff
statement: Farmer mistakes the inscription found on a banded bird for cooking instructions.

title: Did a Woman Mistakenly Use Glitter Spray Instead of Feminine Deodorant?
subtitle: Sometimes you really do need to pay attention to things other people shouldn't see.
statement: A woman mistakenly used her daughter's glitter spray instead of feminine deodorant in preparation for a visit to the gynecologist.

title: Gun-Toting Grannies
subtitle: Did an old lady pull a gun on men she found sitting in her car?
author: Snopes Staff
statement: An old lady pulls a gun on men she finds sitting in her car and forces them out . . . only to discover once they decamp that it's not her car.

title: RV Gas Siphoner Gets Mouthful of Sewage
subtitle: Ever hear the urban legend about a gas-siphoning thief who accidentally gets a mouthful of sewage?
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A gas-siphoning thief got a mouthful he'll never forget when he tried to drain the wrong tank on an RV.

title: San Antonio Ghost Children
subtitle: Do the protective little ghosts of children killed at a railway crossing push stalled cars off the tracks?
author: Snopes Staff
statement: The protective ghosts of little children killed at a railway crossing push stalled cars off the tracks.

title: Drunk Groom Accidentally Returned Home from His Honeymoon
subtitle: Group returns soused young man to his hometown, not realizing he's a newly-married groom on his honeymoon.

title: Prostitution Medallion
subtitle: The exotic foreign medallion worn so proudly by a society matron bore an embarrassing inscription identifying her as a licensed prostitute.
statement: A woman was embarrassed to find her exotic foreign medallion bore an inscription identifying her as a prostitute.

title: Pop Quiz Announced in Paper
subtitle: Did a journalism instructor announce a pop quiz by running an ad in the morning paper?
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A journalism professor who promises at the beginning of the semester that he will never give an unannounced test surprises his class one day with a pop quiz. Over the students' protests, the instructor points out that he had run an ad in that morning's local paper announcing the test.

title: Seeded Field Prank
subtitle: Student working on thesis spreads birdseed on school football field every day.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A student dresses as a referee and spreads birdseed on the school football field every day during the summer; at the school's first home game that fall, the field becomes inundated with birds as soon as the referees step onto the field.
